title.narrative: OUTPUT 1.5 Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene (WASH)

description.narrative: Output 1.5. By 2025, the Government and stakeholders at national and subnational level will have increased capacity to sustainably increase access to and use of quality/safe drinking water, improved sanitation and positive hygiene practices in rural and poor urban households and communities, as well as institutions, in both development and humanitarian situations, which contributes to Climate Change, Disaster Risks And Envionmental Degradation, Reducing Child Poverty, Safe And Equitable Water, Sanitation And Hygiene Services And Practices, Water, Sanitation And Hygiene Systems And Empowerment Of Communities, Water, Sanitation And Hygiene Systems And Empowerment Of Communities (Covid). UNICEF aims to achieve this through Community Engagement, Social And Behaviour Change, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building, Systems Strengthening To Leave No One Behind. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: 1.By 2025, new-borns, children and adolescent boys and girls, especially the most disadvantaged and those living in humanitarian situations, have increased access to and use of quality integrated health, nutrition, HIV and early stimulation services and benefit from a more nurturing, protective and clean environment

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Output 1.5. By 2025, the Government and stakeholders at national and subnational level will have increased capacity to sustainablyincrease access to and use of quality/safe drinking water, improved sanitation and positive hygiene practices in rural and poorurban households and communities, as well as institutions, in both development and humanitarian situations

description.narrative: UNICEF positioned WASH in the national climate dialogue, resulting in the inclusion of WASH in the Nationally Determined Contributions (NDC) document. The climate risk assessment for WASH was also finalized. The national roadmap for ODF and basic sanitation was released while the draft WASH in health facilities guidelines and micro-plan were completed and the micro-plan for WASH in schools was launched. The annual target was substantially surpassed; 68 schools (target: 54) were provided with WASH facilities and WASH supplies benefitted 577,000 persons (target: 280,000) in the COVID-19 response, strengthening IPC in 586 health facilities and 463 schools and corresponding communities. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:09/01/2022
